The contract itself should already include details about the provider, services, charges, communication methods, safeguards, contract changes, and redress options [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. This ensures that the Customer has all necessary information both in the contract and upon request.
rag_answer: During the contract period, a Third Party Provider must furnish the Customer with specific information as outlined in the governing contract and any additional details requested by the Customer. The contract should already include the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 before the Customer is bound by it [#P:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8]. Additionally, the Third Party Provider is obligated to maintain records of what Specified Information has been requested, accessed, processed, and transferred, as well as any information obtained during the customer onboarding process [#P:e2c52aaf-b2e8-4e82-93a3-8f3b17b250b9]. If the Customer requests information on individual Third Party Transactions, the provider must supply details such as transaction references, amounts, charges, exchange rates, and transaction dates at least once per month free of charge [#P:a488bfea-28d5-485d-867e-0e84f4523bfa]. Furthermore, if a Third Party Transaction is initiated by the Customer, the provider must, upon request, give a breakdown of all charges payable by the Customer [#P:e9417e8d-2032-4a16-922e-a0921ba21567]. These obligations ensure transparency and accountability during the contract period.

question: What are the obligations of a Third Party Provider regarding changes to the Governing Contract, and what specific information must be included in the Governing Contract as per the regulatory requirements?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider must notify the Customer of any proposed changes to the existing terms of the Governing Contract or the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 at least two months before these changes take effect [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f]. The Governing Contract must include specific information about the Third Party Provider, such as their name, address, and contact details in ADGM, as well as details about the Third Party Services, including a description of the services and the procedure for consent to transactions [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. Additionally, the contract must cover charges, communication methods, safeguards, and corrective measures, as well as terms for changes and termination of the contract [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].
rag_answer: A Third Party Provider has specific obligations regarding changes to the Governing Contract and the inclusion of certain information within it. The Governing Contract must contain detailed information about the Third Party Provider, the services offered, charges, communication methods, safeguards, and redress options, among other elements [#P:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. When changes to the Governing Contract are proposed, the Third Party Provider must notify the Customer at least two months before the changes take effect, unless otherwise specified [#P:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f]. If unilateral changes are allowed, the Provider must inform the Customer that they will be deemed to have accepted the changes unless they object before the changes take effect, and that they have the right to terminate the contract without charge before the changes are implemented [#P:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468]. These obligations ensure transparency and protect the rights of the Customer in the contractual relationship with the Third Party Provider.

question: When must a Third Party Provider tell a Customer about changes to their contract, and what details need to be in the contract?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider must inform the Customer about any changes to the contract terms or specified information at least two months before the changes happen [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f]. The contract must include details like the provider's name and contact information, a description of the services, how to consent to transactions, and information about charges and communication [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. It should also cover safeguards, corrective measures, and terms for changing or ending the contract [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].
rag_answer: A Third Party Provider must inform a Customer about changes to their contract at least two months before the changes are set to take effect. This requirement ensures that the Customer has adequate time to review and respond to the proposed changes. [#P:29dd8b53] The Governing Contract must include specific details such as the name and contact details of the Third Party Provider, a description of the services, charges, communication methods, safeguards, and the Customer's rights regarding changes and termination of the contract. [#P:c00769cc] If the Third Party Provider is allowed to make unilateral changes, they must inform the Customer that they will be deemed to have accepted the changes unless they notify otherwise before the changes take effect. Additionally, the Customer has the right to terminate the contract without charge before the changes are implemented. [#P:e589a1c4] These provisions ensure transparency and protect the Customer's rights in the contractual relationship.

question: Under what conditions may changes in exchange rates be applied immediately and without notice, and how must these conditions be reflected in the Governing Contract between a Third Party Provider and their Customers?
gold_answer: Changes in exchange rates may be applied immediately and without notice if such a right is agreed under the Governing Contract and the changes are based on the Reference Exchange Rate information provided to the Customer in accordance with Rule 20.2.2, or if the changes are more favorable to the Customer [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2]. The Governing Contract between a Third Party Provider and their Customers must include details of the exchange rates to be applied or, if Reference Exchange Rates are to be used, the method of calculating the relevant date for determining such rates [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. Furthermore, if agreed, the application of changes in Reference Exchange Rates and the information requirements relating to any such changes must also be included [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].
rag_answer: Changes in exchange rates may be applied immediately and without notice under specific conditions, which must be clearly reflected in the Governing Contract between a Third Party Provider and their Customers. Firstly, such immediate changes are permissible if the right to do so is explicitly agreed upon in the Governing Contract, and these changes are based on the Reference Exchange Rate information that has been provided to the Customer in accordance with the relevant rules [#P:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2]. Additionally, changes can be made without notice if they are more favorable to the Customer [#P:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2]. Furthermore, any change in the exchange rate used in Third Party Transactions must be implemented and calculated in a neutral manner that does not discriminate collectively against Customers [#P:cdf0794d-2057-4264-a34d-0bbdd1761593]. These conditions ensure that the process is fair and transparent, protecting the interests of the Customers while allowing the Third Party Provider to adjust exchange rates as necessary.

question: When can exchange rates change right away without telling the Customer, and what must the contract with a Third Party Provider include about these rates?
gold_answer: Exchange rates can change immediately without notice if the contract allows it and the changes are based on the Reference Exchange Rate information given to the Customer, or if the changes benefit the Customer [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2]. The contract with a Third Party Provider must include details about the exchange rates or how to calculate them if Reference Exchange Rates are used [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. It should also cover how changes in these rates will be applied and what information must be provided about such changes if agreed [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].
rag_answer: Exchange rates can change immediately and without notice to the Customer if the right to do so is agreed upon in the Governing Contract and the changes are based on the Reference Exchange Rate information provided to the Customer, or if the changes are more favorable to the Customer [#P:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2]. For contracts with a Third Party Provider, it is essential that any change in the exchange rate used in Third Party Transactions is implemented and calculated in a neutral manner that does not discriminate collectively against Customers [#P:cdf0794d-2057-4264-a34d-0bbdd1761593]. Additionally, the Third Party Provider must provide or make available to the Customer, immediately after the initiation of a Third Party Transaction, the actual exchange rate used or a reference to it, and, if applicable, the amount of the Payment Transaction after currency conversion [#P:bdcc781c-2074-4a3f-b425-2ec77aee973a]. These provisions ensure transparency and fairness in the application of exchange rates in contractual agreements.

question: What are the obligations of a Third Party Provider regarding the notification of refusal of a Third Party Transaction, and how must this be reflected in the Governing Contract with their Customer?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider is obligated to notify the Customer of the refusal of a Third Party Transaction in the manner agreed upon, as specified in Rule 20.2.2 [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575]. This requirement must be reflected in the Governing Contract, which should detail the means of communication agreed between the parties for the transmission of such notifications [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].
rag_answer: A Third Party Provider has specific obligations regarding the notification of refusal of a Third Party Transaction, which must be clearly reflected in the Governing Contract with their Customer. Firstly, the Third Party Provider is required to notify the Customer of the refusal at the earliest opportunity, ensuring that the Customer is promptly informed of the decision [#P:92475ad2-7c49-42c4-8e06-27bc0f4bd130]. The notification must be provided in the manner agreed upon in the contract, as specified in Rule 20.2.2 [#P:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575]. Additionally, where possible, the notification should include the reasons for the refusal and outline the procedure the Customer must follow to rectify any issues or factual errors that led to the refusal [#P:40886582-7e5f-459a-81f3-eff8dbc92e10]. These obligations ensure transparency and provide the Customer with the necessary information to address any problems that may have caused the refusal. The Governing Contract should clearly articulate these requirements to ensure both parties understand their rights and responsibilities in the event of a transaction refusal.

question: How should a Third Party Provider tell a Customer if they refuse a transaction, and what must be in the contract about this?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider must inform the Customer of a transaction refusal in the agreed manner, as outlined in Rule 20.2.2 [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575]. The contract must include details about how the parties will communicate such notifications [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].
rag_answer: A Third Party Provider must notify a Customer at the earliest opportunity if they refuse to execute a transaction. This notification must be provided in the manner agreed upon as set out in Rule 20.2.2 [#P:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575]. Where possible, the notification should include the reasons for the refusal and the procedure the Customer must follow to rectify any issues or factual errors that led to the refusal [#P:40886582-7e5f-459a-81f3-eff8dbc92e10]. This ensures that the Customer is informed promptly and has the necessary information to address any problems that may have caused the refusal. The contract between the Third Party Provider and the Customer should clearly outline these notification requirements, including the agreed manner of communication and the obligation to provide reasons and rectification procedures when feasible. This approach helps maintain transparency and allows the Customer to take corrective action if needed.

question: What are the obligations of a Third Party Provider when proposing unilateral changes to the Governing Contract, and what rights does the Customer have in response to such proposals?
gold_answer: When a Third Party Provider intends to make unilateral changes to the Governing Contract, it must inform the Customer of the proposed changes at least two months before they are set to take effect [#TGT:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f]. The Customer must be notified that they will be deemed to have accepted the changes unless they notify the Third Party Provider otherwise before the proposed effective date [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468]. Additionally, the Customer has the right to terminate the Governing Contract without charge at any time before the changes take effect [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468].
rag_answer: When a Third Party Provider proposes unilateral changes to the Governing Contract, it has specific obligations to inform the Customer and provide them with certain rights. Firstly, the Third Party Provider must notify the Customer of the proposed changes no later than two months before they are set to take effect, ensuring the Customer has adequate time to consider the changes [#P:29dd8b53]. The notification must include a statement that unless the Customer objects before the proposed date of entry into force, they will be deemed to have accepted the changes [#P:e589a1c4]. Additionally, the Customer must be informed of their right to terminate the Governing Contract without any charges at any time before the changes take effect [#P:e589a1c4]. These obligations ensure that the Customer is fully aware of the changes and has the opportunity to either accept them or terminate the contract without penalty. This process is designed to protect the Customer's interests by providing them with sufficient notice and the option to exit the contract if they do not agree with the proposed changes.

question: If a Third Party Provider wants to change the Governing Contract, what must they do, and what can the Customer do if they don't agree?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider must inform the Customer about any changes to the Governing Contract at least two months before these changes are supposed to happen [#TGT:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f]. The Customer will automatically accept the changes unless they tell the Third Party Provider they disagree before the changes take effect [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468]. The Customer can also choose to end the contract without any fees before the changes start [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468].
rag_answer: If a Third Party Provider wishes to change the Governing Contract, they must adhere to specific procedures to ensure transparency and fairness to the Customer. Firstly, the Provider must notify the Customer of any proposed changes to the existing terms of the Governing Contract or the specified information at least two months before these changes are set to take effect [#P:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f]. The notification must inform the Customer that if they do not respond before the proposed date of the changes, they will be deemed to have accepted them [#P:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468]. Additionally, the Customer has the right to terminate the Governing Contract without any charge at any time before the changes come into force [#P:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468]. This ensures that the Customer is not bound by terms they do not agree with and provides them with a clear exit strategy if they find the changes unacceptable. The Governing Contract must also include terms under which the Customer will be deemed to have accepted changes unless they notify the Provider otherwise [#P:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].

question: Under what conditions must a Third Party Provider notify a Customer of changes to the Governing Contract, and how does this relate to immediate changes in exchange rates?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider is required to notify a Customer of any proposed changes to the existing terms of the Governing Contract or the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 at least two months before these changes take effect [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f]. However, changes in exchange rates can be applied immediately and without notice if the Governing Contract allows for such a right and the changes are based on the Reference Exchange Rate information provided in accordance with Rule 20.2.2 [#TGT:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2]. This immediate application is also permissible if the changes are more favourable to the Customer [#TGT:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2].
rag_answer: A Third Party Provider must notify a Customer of changes to the Governing Contract when it intends to make unilateral changes. The Customer must be informed that they will be deemed to have accepted the changes unless they notify the Third Party Provider to the contrary before the proposed date of entry into force. Additionally, the Customer has the right to terminate the Governing Contract without charge at any time before the changes take effect [#P:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468]. However, changes in exchange rates can be applied immediately and without notice if such a right is agreed under the Governing Contract and the changes are based on the Reference Exchange Rate information provided to the Customer, or if the changes are more favorable to the Customer [#P:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2]. This means that while general contractual changes require notification and offer the Customer a chance to respond, specific changes in exchange rates may bypass this requirement under certain conditions, particularly if they benefit the Customer or are pre-agreed in the contract.

question: When does a Third Party Provider have to tell a Customer about changes to the Governing Contract, and how does this compare to changes in exchange rates?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider must inform a Customer about changes to the Governing Contract or specified information at least two months before they take effect [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f]. In contrast, changes in exchange rates can happen right away without notice if the contract allows it and the rates are based on provided Reference Exchange Rate information [#TGT:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2]. Immediate changes are also allowed if they benefit the Customer [#TGT:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2].
rag_answer: A Third Party Provider must inform a Customer about changes to the Governing Contract if the provider is allowed to make unilateral changes. The Customer must be informed that they will be deemed to have accepted the changes unless they notify the provider to the contrary before the proposed date of entry into force. Additionally, the Customer has the right to terminate the Governing Contract without charge at any time before the changes take effect [#P:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468]. In contrast, changes in exchange rates can be applied immediately and without notice if such a right is agreed under the Governing Contract and the changes are based on the Reference Exchange Rate information provided to the Customer, or if the changes are more favorable to the Customer [#P:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2]. This means that while contractual changes require prior notification and offer the Customer a chance to reject or terminate the contract, exchange rate changes can be implemented more swiftly under certain conditions, reflecting a more flexible approach to rate adjustments compared to contractual amendments.

question: Under what conditions may a Customer and a Third Party Provider agree in writing to exclude the application of Rule 20.8.2, and how does this affect the Customer's ability to withdraw consent to a Third Party Transaction?
gold_answer: A Customer that is not a Natural Person may agree in writing with a Third Party Provider to exclude the application of Rule 20.8.2, which pertains to the revocation of a Payment Order [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. This agreement allows the parties to set different terms regarding the revocation of Payment Orders, potentially affecting the Customer's ability to withdraw consent to a Third Party Transaction. Normally, the Customer can withdraw consent to a Third Party Transaction at any time before it can no longer be revoked as per Rule 20.8.2 [#TGT:84c622c5-b22e-4360-9f94-1bd99e99f12c]. However, if Rule 20.8.2 is excluded by agreement, the standard revocation terms may not apply, and the parties may establish alternative conditions for consent withdrawal.
rag_answer: A Customer and a Third Party Provider may agree in writing to exclude the application of Rule 20.8.2 when the Customer is not a Natural Person. This agreement allows them to bypass the standard rules regarding the revocation of a Payment Order, which includes the withdrawal of consent to a Third Party Transaction. [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] Under normal circumstances, a Customer can withdraw consent to a Third Party Transaction at any time before the transaction can no longer be revoked as per Rule 20.8.2. [#P:84c622c5-b22e-4360-9f94-1bd99e99f12c] However, if the parties agree in writing to exclude Rule 20.8.2, the Customer's ability to withdraw consent is altered, as the standard revocation process no longer applies. This agreement must be documented in writing, ensuring both parties are clear on the terms and conditions that deviate from the standard regulatory framework. It is important to note that this exclusion is only applicable when the Customer is not a Natural Person, and both parties must mutually consent to this arrangement. [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]

question: If a Customer is not a Natural Person, when can they agree with a Third Party Provider to ignore Rule 20.8.2, and what does this mean for stopping a Third Party Transaction?
gold_answer: A Customer who is not a Natural Person can agree with a Third Party Provider to ignore Rule 20.8.2 if they put it in writing [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. Rule 20.8.2 deals with when a Payment Order can be revoked. Normally, a Customer can stop a Third Party Transaction before it reaches a point where it can't be revoked anymore [#TGT:84c622c5-b22e-4360-9f94-1bd99e99f12c]. If they agree to ignore this rule, they might set different terms for when they can stop a transaction.
rag_answer: A Customer that is not a Natural Person can agree with a Third Party Provider to disregard Rule 20.8.2, which pertains to the revocation of a Payment Order, under certain conditions. Specifically, they may enter into a written agreement to this effect, allowing them to bypass the standard rule that prohibits the revocation of a Third Party Transaction initiated through another Third Party Provider [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. This means that, under such an agreement, the Customer may have the flexibility to revoke a Third Party Transaction even if it was initiated through another provider, which is typically not allowed [#P:a679f3ff-1488-406b-bc4d-36c38a2c7a1f]. This agreement must be explicitly documented in writing between the Customer and the Third Party Provider, ensuring that both parties are clear on the terms and conditions under which the revocation can occur. This exception provides a tailored approach for non-natural person Customers, allowing them to negotiate terms that better fit their operational needs.

question: Under what conditions may a Customer who is not a Natural Person agree with a Third Party Provider to exclude the applicability of Rule 20.8.2, and how does this affect the withdrawal of consent for Third Party Transactions?
gold_answer: A Customer who is not a Natural Person may agree in writing with a Third Party Provider to exclude the applicability of Rule 20.8.2, which pertains to the revocation of a Payment Order [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. If such an agreement is in place, the Customer may not be subject to the standard provisions regarding the withdrawal of consent for Third Party Transactions. However, in the absence of such an agreement, the Customer retains the right to withdraw consent to a series of Third Party Transactions at any time, and any transactions that have been consented to but not yet executed at the time of withdrawal will no longer be considered authorised [#TGT:e4c92e77-6fe0-46b4-a71f-9f3a479ee273].
rag_answer: A Customer who is not a Natural Person may agree with a Third Party Provider to exclude the applicability of Rule 20.8.2, which pertains to the revocation of a Payment Order, by entering into a written agreement. This agreement allows the parties to bypass certain rules, including those related to the withdrawal of consent for Third Party Transactions, as specified in Rule 20.7.3 and 20.7.4 [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. Under normal circumstances, a Customer can withdraw consent to an individual Third Party Transaction at any time before the transaction can no longer be revoked, as outlined in Rule 20.8.2 [#P:84c622c5-b22e-4360-9f94-1bd99e99f12c]. However, if Rule 20.8.2 is excluded by agreement, the standard procedure for revocation and withdrawal of consent may not apply, potentially altering the timing and conditions under which consent can be withdrawn. This flexibility allows the Customer and the Third Party Provider to tailor the terms of their transactions to better suit their specific needs, provided they mutually agree in writing to such terms.

question: If a business customer and a Third Party Provider agree in writing, can they ignore the rule about revoking a payment order, and what happens to transactions if consent is withdrawn?
gold_answer: A business customer and a Third Party Provider can agree in writing to ignore the rule about revoking a payment order, which is Rule 20.8.2 [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. If they don't make such an agreement, the customer can still withdraw consent for a series of transactions at any time. Any transactions that were agreed to but not yet done when consent is withdrawn will not be considered authorised anymore [#TGT:e4c92e77-6fe0-46b4-a71f-9f3a479ee273].
rag_answer: A business customer and a Third Party Provider can agree in writing to disregard the rule about revoking a payment order. This is permissible when the customer is not a natural person, allowing them to opt out of certain rules, including Rule 20.8.2, which pertains to the revocation of a Payment Order [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. If consent is withdrawn, the specific rules governing the withdrawal of consent, such as Rules 20.7.3 and 20.7.4, can also be disregarded if there is a written agreement between the business customer and the Third Party Provider [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. However, it is important to note that a Third Party Transaction cannot be revoked after the Third Party Provider has confirmed receipt, unless there is an agreement between the customer and the provider [#P:ea749dbf-4f0a-472b-8330-5f256305db10; #P:aa1667a8-fe44-4994-b584-b9f647288823]. This flexibility allows business customers and providers to tailor their agreements to better suit their operational needs, provided all parties consent to the terms.

question: Under what circumstances is a Customer not liable for losses from unauthorised Third Party Transactions, and what obligations does a Third Party Provider have regarding notification means?
gold_answer: A Customer is not liable for losses from unauthorised Third Party Transactions if they have not acted fraudulently or with intent or gross negligence in failing to protect their Personalised Security Credentials. The Customer must notify the Third Party Provider of any loss, theft, misappropriation, or unauthorised use of their credentials in the agreed manner. The Third Party Provider is obligated to ensure that appropriate means are available at all times for such notifications. If the Third Party Provider fails to provide these means in accordance with Rule 20.9.2, or fails to apply Strong Customer Authentication, the Customer is not liable for the losses. Additionally, if the notification is made after the Customer becomes aware of the issue, the Customer's liability is further mitigated [#SRC:5adbd32c-9d2c-4fd5-a1e8-060fba49ae90][#TGT:d8fc441e-0a9e-4a18-bbd8-2cfe0dd0ee07].
rag_answer: A Customer is not liable for losses from unauthorised Third Party Transactions under specific conditions. These include situations where the Customer has not acted fraudulently or with intent or gross negligence in failing to protect their Personalised Security Credentials from unauthorized access. Additionally, the Customer is not liable for losses if the unauthorised transaction occurs after they have notified the Third Party Provider in the agreed manner about the loss, theft, misappropriation, or unauthorized use of their credentials. Furthermore, liability is also waived if the Third Party Provider has failed to provide appropriate means for notification as required by Rule 20.9.2, or if the Provider has not applied Strong Customer Authentication [#P:5adbd32c-9d2c-4fd5-a1e8-060fba49ae90]. The Third Party Provider is obligated to ensure that there are appropriate means for the Customer to notify them of any issues with their Personalised Security Credentials. Failure to provide such means can result in the Provider being liable for any resulting unauthorised transactions [#P:5adbd32c-9d2c-4fd5-a1e8-060fba49ae90]. These provisions ensure that liability is appropriately assigned based on the actions and responsibilities of both the Customer and the Third Party Provider.

question: When is a Customer not responsible for losses from unauthorised transactions, and what must a Third Party Provider do about notifications?
gold_answer: A Customer is not responsible for losses from unauthorised transactions if they have not been careless or dishonest with their security details. They need to tell the Third Party Provider about any problems with their security details as soon as they know. The Third Party Provider must always have a way for the Customer to report these issues. If the Third Party Provider does not provide this, or if they do not use Strong Customer Authentication, the Customer is not responsible for the losses. Also, if the Customer reports the issue after they find out, they are not liable for those losses [#SRC:5adbd32c-9d2c-4fd5-a1e8-060fba49ae90][#TGT:d8fc441e-0a9e-4a18-bbd8-2cfe0dd0ee07].
rag_answer: A Customer is not responsible for losses from unauthorised Third Party Transactions if they have not acted fraudulently or with intent or gross negligence in failing to protect their Personalised Security Credentials. Specifically, the Customer is not liable for such losses if they have notified the Third Party Provider in the agreed manner upon becoming aware of the loss, theft, misappropriation, or unauthorised use of their credentials, if the Third Party Provider has failed to provide appropriate means for notification, or if the Third Party Provider has not applied Strong Customer Authentication [#P:5adbd32c-9d2c-4fd5-a1e8-060fba49ae90]. Upon receiving a notification from the Customer that a Third Party Transaction is unauthorised or incorrectly executed, the Third Party Provider is obligated to inform the Primary Financial Institution of the Customers notification [#P:f47ebd48-ff65-47e7-9ee5-9ce60c041605]. This ensures that the necessary parties are aware of the issue and can take appropriate action. It is crucial for both the Customer and the Third Party Provider to adhere to these procedures to manage liability and ensure proper handling of unauthorised transactions.

question: Under what conditions may a Benchmark Administrator incorporate rules and practice standards into the rules of a Recognised Body, Multilateral Trading Facility, or Organised Trading Facility, and what responsibilities must be outlined in these standards?
gold_answer: A Benchmark Administrator may incorporate rules and practice standards into the rules of a Recognised Body, Multilateral Trading Facility, or Organised Trading Facility if the Specified Benchmark is determined solely on the basis of information from a market operated by these entities and the Benchmark Administrator is also the same entity [#SRC:61e2c835-b6ed-4251-af9c-d261a5364a28]. These standards must outline responsibilities related to the Specified Benchmark, including those applicable to Specified Benchmark Information Providers, other Persons providing information from outside the ADGM, and the Benchmark Administrator itself [#TGT:4737f4ff-3c18-4805-ac10-40d295d242ac].
rag_answer: A Benchmark Administrator may incorporate rules and practice standards into the rules of a Recognised Body, Multilateral Trading Facility, or Organised Trading Facility under specific conditions. These conditions are that the Specified Benchmark is determined solely based on information from a market operated by such entities, and the Benchmark Administrator is also the same entity as the Recognised Body, Multilateral Trading Facility, or Organised Trading Facility. Additionally, this incorporation must not affect the Benchmark Administrators ability to comply with its regulatory obligations [#P:61e2c835-b6ed-4251-af9c-d261a5364a28]. The responsibilities outlined in these standards must include the development of rules and practice standards that set out the responsibilities for Specified Benchmark Information Providers, other persons providing information from outside the ADGM, and the Benchmark Administrator itself [#P:4737f4ff-3c18-4805-ac10-40d295d242ac]. These standards ensure that the Benchmark Administrator maintains effective organisational and governance arrangements, maintains market integrity, ensures confidentiality and integrity of information, and manages conflicts of interest [#P:f4b8a342-0063-445a-88a6-9acb69f92f58].

question: When can a Benchmark Administrator add its rules to a Recognised Body's rules, and what must these rules include?
gold_answer: A Benchmark Administrator can add its rules to a Recognised Body's rules if the benchmark is based only on information from a market run by that Recognised Body, and the Administrator is the same entity [#SRC:61e2c835-b6ed-4251-af9c-d261a5364a28]. These rules must include responsibilities for Specified Benchmark Information Providers, people providing information from outside the ADGM, and the Benchmark Administrator [#TGT:4737f4ff-3c18-4805-ac10-40d295d242ac].
rag_answer: A Benchmark Administrator can incorporate its rules into the rules of a Recognised Body, Multilateral Trading Facility, or Organised Trading Facility when the Specified Benchmark is determined solely based on information from a market operated by one of these entities, and the Benchmark Administrator is also that entity. This integration is permissible provided it does not compromise the Benchmark Administrators ability to meet its regulatory obligations [#P:61e2c835-b6ed-4251-af9c-d261a5364a28]. The rules that must be included are those that set out the responsibilities of the Specified Benchmark Information Providers, other persons providing information from outside the ADGM, and the Benchmark Administrator itself [#P:4737f4ff-3c18-4805-ac10-40d295d242ac]. This ensures that all parties involved in the administration of the Specified Benchmark are aware of their duties and the standards they must adhere to, maintaining the integrity and reliability of the benchmark process.

question: What are the compliance requirements for an Authorised Person using delivery and/or storage facilities for Accepted Spot Commodities from jurisdictions outside the ADGM, and how do these requirements relate to Rule 22.4.2?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must ensure that any delivery and/or storage facility used for Accepted Spot Commodities from jurisdictions outside the ADGM operates under rules and regulations equivalent to those in the Abu Dhabi Global Market [#TGT:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5]. Additionally, these facilities must comply with all applicable laws in the relevant jurisdiction, including local port conditions, customs requirements, anticorruption laws, and taxation requirements [#TGT:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5]. The facilities must also adhere to international standards for storage and delivery mechanisms, such as IOSCOs Good and Sound Practices, and have OHSAS 18001 or equivalent certification standards [#TGT:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5]. Furthermore, appropriate audit, control, and insurance arrangements must be in place to cover various risks [#TGT:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5]. These requirements are in line with Rule 22.4.2, which mandates that facilities outside the ADGM must meet equivalent standards to those within the ADGM [#SRC:4230a066-37c4-4630-bb93-d9a0ed5bc81b].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person using delivery and/or storage facilities for Accepted Spot Commodities from jurisdictions outside the ADGM must comply with specific regulatory requirements to ensure these facilities meet the standards set by the FSRA. Firstly, the Authorised Person must submit details to the FSRA demonstrating how each facility, whether inside or outside ADGM, complies with the requirements outlined in Rule 22.4.2(a) to (e) [#P:e246e133-be84-43b6-9018-08d6dd75dd9e]. question: When an Authorised Person is dealing with Accepted Spot Commodities, how should they read the terms Recognised Body and Financial Instrument in the rules they must follow?

question: How must an Authorised Person providing custody for Accepted Spot Commodities interpret references to Client Assets and Investments in Chapters 14, 15, and 16 of COBS?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person providing custody for Accepted Spot Commodities must interpret references to Client Assets in Chapters 14, 15, and 16 of COBS as including Accepted Spot Commodities [#SRC:89eab6b1-87b1-4aee-956d-d75d4f8c556a]. Additionally, references to Investment or Investments, and consequently Client Investments, should also be read as encompassing Accepted Spot Commodities [#SRC:89eab6b1-87b1-4aee-956d-d75d4f8c556a]. This interpretation is necessary to ensure compliance with the requirements set out in these chapters [#TGT:23d45c5e-fd58-4146-bd4e-5dfef1a17395].

question: What are the obligations of an Authorised Person regarding the operation and monitoring of a Spot Commodity Auction Platform, and how must these obligations ensure the orderly conduct and protection of participants?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to have adequate arrangements to operate a Spot Commodity Auction Platform, which includes the ability to assess, mitigate, and manage risks associated with its performance [#SRC:4056cfbb-4512-4279-a074-7577632f9653]. Additionally, the Authorised Person must ensure that business conducted on the platform is orderly and provides proper protection to participants. This involves implementing transparent rules and procedures for fair and orderly auctions, establishing criteria for efficient transaction execution, and ensuring the settlement of the Accepted Spot Commodity or transfer of the Spot Commodity Title [#TGT:1970af23-583d-4eee-8691-1db4637d6329]. The Authorised Person must also monitor bids and transactions, perform the full technical operation of the platform, and maintain contingency arrangements for disruptions [#SRC:4056cfbb-4512-4279-a074-7577632f9653]. Furthermore, they must adopt measures to prevent Market Abuse or Financial Crime and ensure relevant information is available to participants [#TGT:1970af23-583d-4eee-8691-1db4637d6329].

Firstly, the Authorised Person must have adequate systems and controls to operate the platform, assess and manage risks, and monitor bids and transactions by participants [#P:4056cfbb-4512-4279-a074-7577632f9653]. Additionally, they must ensure that the platform is used in a manner that reduces the risk of Market Abuse or Financial Crime, and facilitates the detection and monitoring of such activities [#P:1970af23-583d-4eee-8691-1db4637d6329]. The platform must have transparent rules and procedures to ensure fair and orderly auctions, establish objective criteria for transaction execution, and manage the settlement or transfer of commodities [#P:1970af23-583d-4eee-8691-1db4637d6329]. Furthermore, the Authorised Person is responsible for making relevant information available to participants and recording transactions executed on the platform [#P:1970af23-583d-4eee-8691-1db4637d6329]. These obligations are subject to the approval of the Regulator and compliance with specific rules [#P:78436e63-6691-4ac5-b00c-44100dfed5e6]. By fulfilling these requirements, the Authorised Person ensures the platform operates effectively and participants are adequately protected.

question: How must an Authorised Person ensure compliance with Rule 23.10.2 when dealing with referrals from unregulated Persons involving rewards?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to have adequate systems and controls in place to ensure compliance with Rule 23.10.2 [#SRC:83c756d9-3a60-4744-a066-c56fbb204047]. This includes not accepting referrals of Retail Clients from unregulated Persons if such referrals involve the disbursement of any reward, whether monetary or non-monetary, from the Authorised Person to the unregulated Person [#TGT:eb92921c-abc1-4657-8789-809b31e91b25].
rag_answer: To ensure compliance with Rule 23.10.2, an Authorised Person must not accept referrals of Retail Clients from unregulated Persons if such referrals involve the disbursement of any reward, whether monetary or non-monetary, to the unregulated Person. This rule is designed to prevent conflicts of interest and ensure that the Authorised Person's actions are aligned with their duty to their Clients. The Authorised Person must have robust systems and controls, including policies and procedures, to prevent offering, giving, soliciting, or accepting inducements that could conflict with their duties to Clients. However, if the Authorised Person reasonably believes that the Client's interests are better served by the referral, any commission or benefit received in respect of such a referral is not considered a prohibited inducement under the rules, provided it does not conflict with the Authorised Person's duties to the Client [#P:eb92921c-abc1-4657-8789-809b31e91b25][#P:638e0b7e-8502-41eb-a1f3-c49132880481].

question: What are the obligations of an Authorised Person regarding the provision and acknowledgment of a risk disclosure statement before opening a trading account for a Retail Client to trade OTC Leveraged Products, and what specific warnings must be included in the risk disclosure statement?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must fulfill several obligations before opening a trading account for a Retail Client to trade OTC Leveraged Products. Firstly, the Authorised Person is required to provide a separate risk disclosure statement to the Retail Client as part of the onboarding process, ensuring it is delivered in good time before any business is conducted [#SRC:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8]. This statement must include a prominent warning about the risk of losing substantially more than the initial margin posted [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955]. Additionally, the statement should inform the Retail Client of the potential to lose all capital outlay and any unredeemed profits, the rapid accumulation of losses, and the amplification of losses through leverage [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955]. The Authorised Person must also obtain a documented acknowledgment from the Retail Client confirming receipt and understanding of the risks, provide a duplicate of this acknowledgment to the client, and maintain a record of it in compliance with record-keeping requirements [#SRC:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8].
rag_answer:
An Authorised Person must fulfill specific obligations before opening a trading account for a Retail Client to trade OTC Leveraged Products. These obligations include providing a risk disclosure statement and obtaining acknowledgment from the client. The risk disclosure statement must include several specific warnings. 

- The Authorised Person must provide a separate risk disclosure statement to the Retail Client as part of the onboarding process before conducting any business. [#P:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8]
- The Retail Client must acknowledge in writing that they have received, reviewed, and understood the risk disclosure statement, and the Authorised Person must provide a duplicate of this acknowledgment to the client and maintain a record of it. [#P:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8]
- The risk disclosure statement must prominently warn that investing in OTC Leveraged Products involves the risk of losing substantially more than the initial margin posted. [#P:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955]
- It must state that the client is at risk of losing all capital outlay and any profits not redeemed, and that margin trading amplifies losses. [#P:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955]
- The statement should also include performance data showing the percentage of profitable Retail Client accounts for each relevant product over the most recent calendar quarters. [#P:65eb88b2-c08c-4ec4-94ed-dfcf8972cca1]

These steps ensure that Retail Clients are fully informed of the risks associated with trading OTC Leveraged Products.

This comprehensive assessment and documentation process ensures that the Retail Client is fully informed and capable of managing the financial risks associated with trading in OTC Leveraged Products.

question: When does an Authorised Person need to check a Retail Client's financial situation again, and why is this important for OTC Leveraged Products?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must check a Retail Client's financial situation again every year or if something important changes in their finances or risk tolerance before the yearly check [#SRC:98b97356-14ec-44f8-9af4-96ffa1211a76]. This is important because the Authorised Person needs to make sure the client understands the risks and has enough money to handle potential losses before offering OTC Leveraged Products or giving related advice [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person must reassess a Retail Client's financial situation when considering offering OTC Leveraged Products to ensure the client can absorb potential losses without resorting to credit facilities. This is crucial because trading in OTC Leveraged Products involves significant risk, and the client must have sufficient liquid financial resources to handle potential losses. Initially, the Authorised Person must complete an assessment of the Retail Client's skill, experience, knowledge, financial resources, and risk tolerance to reasonably conclude that the client understands the risks and has adequate financial resources [#P:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0]. Additionally, the Authorised Person should consider the client's trading history, professional qualifications, and liquid financial resources to determine their ability to absorb losses [#P:4795ec13-2901-4f85-a230-9e6b9eb6200d]. This assessment is part of the broader obligation to provide a risk disclosure statement and obtain the client's acknowledgment of understanding the risks involved in trading OTC Leveraged Products [#P:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8]. Maintaining accurate records of these assessments and acknowledgments is essential for compliance and client protection.

question: When a Specified Benchmark Information Provider also functions as a Price Reporting Agency, what additional compliance obligations must the Authorised Person fulfill under MIR Rule 3.11.2, considering the requirements for fair and non-discriminatory procedures in price establishment?
gold_answer: When a Specified Benchmark Information Provider also serves as a Price Reporting Agency, the Authorised Person is required to comply with the obligations outlined in MIR Rule 3.11.2, in addition to the specific rules under section 21.4 [#SRC:3af22e09-3d07-428f-8ca0-13b059f75329]. This includes ensuring that the Price Reporting Agency has fair and non-discriminatory procedures for establishing prices of a Financial Instrument, which must be made public [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. The agency must also demonstrate transparency in its methodology and calculations to allow users to understand how benchmarks or indices are derived, including any potential limitations [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a].
rag_answer: When a Specified Benchmark Information Provider also functions as a Price Reporting Agency, the Authorised Person must comply with additional obligations under MIR Rule 3.11.2. These obligations include ensuring that the Price Reporting Agency has fair and non-discriminatory procedures for establishing prices of a Financial Instrument, which must be made public [#P:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. The agency must also demonstrate adequate transparency over the methodology, calculation, and inputs to allow users to understand how the benchmark or index is derived and its potential limitations [#P:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. Furthermore, the agency should prioritize concluded transactions in making assessments and adopt measures to minimize selective reporting where appropriate [#P:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. It is essential for the agency to maintain a good standing and reputation as an independent and objective price reporting agency or index provider, and to have a sound corporate governance framework [#P:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. Additionally, the agency must have adequate arrangements to avoid conflicts of interest among its staff that could materially impact the price establishment process, and it should have mechanisms to resolve complaints about its assessment process and methodology [#P:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. These requirements ensure the integrity and reliability of the price reporting process.

question: If a Specified Benchmark Information Provider is also a Price Reporting Agency, what rules must they follow to ensure fair pricing and transparency?
gold_answer: A Specified Benchmark Information Provider that is also a Price Reporting Agency must adhere to the requirements of MIR Rule 3.11.2, along with the rules specified in section 21.4 [#SRC:3af22e09-3d07-428f-8ca0-13b059f75329]. This includes having fair and non-discriminatory procedures for setting prices of Financial Instruments, which should be publicly available [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. Additionally, the agency must ensure transparency in its pricing methodology and calculations, allowing users to understand how benchmarks or indices are derived and any limitations they may have [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a].
rag_answer: If a Specified Benchmark Information Provider is also a Price Reporting Agency, they must adhere to specific rules to ensure fair pricing and transparency. Firstly, they must have fair and non-discriminatory procedures for establishing prices of a Financial Instrument, which should be made public [#P:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. Additionally, they are required to demonstrate adequate transparency over the methodology, calculation, and inputs to allow users to understand how the benchmark or index is derived and its potential limitations [#P:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. They must also prioritize concluded transactions in making assessments and adopt measures to minimize selective reporting where appropriate [#P:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. Furthermore, they need to maintain a sound corporate governance framework and have arrangements to avoid conflicts of interest that could materially impact the price establishment process [#P:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. Lastly, they must have adequate complaint resolution mechanisms to address any issues regarding their assessment process and methodology [#P:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. These requirements are in addition to the general rules for Specified Benchmark Information Providers, which include maintaining the integrity, accuracy, and reliability of the information provided [#P:1fa96d9b-1383-4529-9b8c-dfda808a161d].

question: How must an Authorised Person manage conflicts of interest when preparing or publishing Investment Research, considering the requirements of Rule 6.4.2 and Principle 7?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is obligated to take reasonable steps to identify and manage conflicts of interest, as required by Rule 6.4.2, which applies in addition to other requirements under FSMR and any related rules [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. Specifically, when preparing or publishing Investment Research, the Authorised Person must have adequate procedures and controls in place [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. Furthermore, compliance with Principle 7, as outlined in Rule 2.2.7, necessitates identifying conflicts of interest between the Authorised Person, including its managers, Employees, Clients, or any person linked by control, and between one Client and another Client, which may arise during the provision of Regulated Activities [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person must manage conflicts of interest when preparing or publishing Investment Research by implementing adequate procedures, systems, and controls to ensure impartiality and compliance with regulatory requirements. This includes the effective supervision and management of Investment Analysts, proactive management of actual or potential conflicts of interest in accordance with Rule 3.5, and ensuring that the Investment Research issued to clients is impartial and contains necessary disclosures as described under Rules 6.4.2 and 6.4.4 [#P:f5c41339-75b8-4442-b55d-231a8de1e012]. Additionally, the requirements of Rule 6.4.2 apply alongside other obligations under FSMR, such as taking reasonable steps to identify and manage conflicts of interest under GEN 3.3.21-3.3.24 [#P:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. It is important to note that these conflicts do not arise if the research is prepared solely for the Authorised Person's own use, such as for proprietary trading, and not for publication [#P:9eff4445-2afc-4c22-9b8a-7e2f95aabaaf]. This comprehensive approach ensures that the integrity of the Investment Research is maintained and that the interests of clients are protected.

question: What steps should an Authorised Person take to handle conflicts of interest when doing Investment Research, based on Rule 6.4.2 and Principle 7?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must take reasonable steps to identify and manage conflicts of interest, as required by Rule 6.4.2, which applies alongside other FSMR requirements [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. When preparing or publishing Investment Research, the Authorised Person should have adequate procedures and controls [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. Additionally, Principle 7 requires identifying conflicts between the Authorised Person, its managers, Employees, Clients, or any person linked by control, and between one Client and another Client, which may arise during Regulated Activities [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319].
rag_answer: To effectively handle conflicts of interest when conducting Investment Research, an Authorised Person must adhere to Rule 6.4.2 and Principle 7 by implementing comprehensive procedures and controls. Firstly, the Authorised Person should take reasonable steps to identify any actual or potential conflicts of interest, which may arise between the Authorised Person, its managers, employees, clients, or any person linked by control, as well as between different clients [#P:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319]. The Authorised Person must ensure that when publishing Investment Research or when a representative makes a public appearance, disclosures are made regarding any financial or material interests of the Investment Analyst or their close relatives, reporting lines and remuneration arrangements that could impair impartiality, and any significant shareholdings or corporate roles related to the Issuer [#P:f618788a-857f-422a-8767-89ab5bdcf733]. Additionally, the Authorised Person is required to have adequate procedures and controls in place to manage these conflicts effectively, as outlined in the broader requirements under FSMR and related rules [#P:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. By following these steps, the Authorised Person can ensure the integrity and impartiality of its Investment Research activities.

question: How must an Authorised Person manage the disclosure of conflicts of interest when preparing or publishing Investment Research, considering the requirements of Rule 6.4.2 and Rule 3.3.23?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to manage conflicts of interest by taking reasonable steps to identify and either prevent or manage them, as outlined in Rule 6.4.2 [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. When preparing or publishing Investment Research, the Authorised Person must ensure that any disclosure of conflicts of interest is made in a durable medium and includes sufficient detail. This detail must be adequate for the Client to make an informed decision regarding the service in which the conflict arises, as specified in Rule 3.3.23 [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9].
rag_answer: To manage the disclosure of conflicts of interest when preparing or publishing Investment Research, an Authorised Person must adhere to specific procedures and controls as outlined in the relevant rules. Firstly, the Authorised Person must ensure that any actual or potential conflicts of interest are proactively managed in accordance with Rule 3.5, which includes taking reasonable steps to identify and either prevent or manage these conflicts [#P:f5c41339-75b8-4442-b55d-231a8de1e012][#P:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. Additionally, the Investment Research must be impartial and contain the necessary disclosures as described under Rules 6.4.2 and 6.4.4 [#P:f5c41339-75b8-4442-b55d-231a8de1e012]. The Authorised Person is also expected to have adequate procedures, systems, and controls to manage effectively any conflicts that arise, as Investment Research is a significant potential source of such conflicts [#P:df47492d-036d-4ec2-8404-0069fbd1145d]. It is important to note that these requirements apply in addition to other obligations under FSMR and related rules, ensuring comprehensive management of conflicts of interest [#P:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. An exception exists where the Investment Research is prepared solely for the Authorised Person's own use, such as for proprietary trading, in which case the same conflicts of interest do not arise [#P:9eff4445-2afc-4c22-9b8a-7e2f95aabaaf].

question: What should an Authorised Person do to handle conflicts of interest when they prepare or publish Investment Research, based on Rule 6.4.2 and Rule 3.3.23?

question: What are the record-keeping obligations of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business regarding Client classification and agreements, and how do these obligations relate to the maintenance period for records?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must include records of Client classification and Client agreements in their Resolution Pack, as specified under Rules 2.7.1 and 3.7.1(d) [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. These records must be maintained for a minimum of six years, as part of the broader requirement to keep sufficient records for each activity and function of the Authorised Person [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2]. This ensures compliance with regulatory standards and facilitates the demonstration of adherence to rules concerning Client interactions and agreements.
rag_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business has specific record-keeping obligations regarding Client classification and agreements. These obligations include maintaining records of Client classification and Client agreements, including any amendments agreed with the Client, as outlined in Rule 3.7.1(d) [#P:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2]. These records must be included in the Resolution Pack, which is a collection of essential documents that an Authorised Person must maintain [#P:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. The maintenance period for these records is a minimum of six years, ensuring that the Authorised Person can demonstrate compliance with regulatory requirements over a significant period [#P:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2]. This requirement ensures that the Authorised Person has a comprehensive and accessible record of its interactions and agreements with Clients, which is crucial for regulatory compliance and effective resolution planning. There are no specific exceptions mentioned in the context provided, indicating that these obligations apply broadly to all Authorised Persons conducting Investment Business.

question: What records about Client classification and agreements must an Authorised Person keep, and for how long?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must keep records of Client classification and Client agreements as part of their Resolution Pack, according to specific rules [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. These records must be kept for at least six years to comply with the requirement to maintain sufficient records for all activities and functions [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2]. This helps ensure that the Authorised Person can show they follow the rules about how they classify and agree with Clients.
rag_answer: An Authorised Person is required to maintain records related to Client classification and agreements for a minimum of six years. Specifically, they must keep documents regarding Client classification as outlined under Chapter 2, which ensures that Clients are appropriately categorized according to the regulatory framework [#P:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2]. Additionally, a record of each Client Agreement, including any subsequent amendments agreed upon with the Client, must be retained. This ensures that there is a clear and traceable history of the contractual relationship between the Authorised Person and the Client [#P:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2]. These records are crucial for demonstrating compliance with regulatory requirements and for resolving any potential disputes or inquiries that may arise. The six-year retention period is a standard requirement for various types of records, ensuring that sufficient historical data is available for regulatory review or audit purposes [#P:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2].

question: Under what conditions is the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement not applicable to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets, and what obligations does the Authorised Person have when it is applicable?
gold_answer: The Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that are included in or track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark, as per Rule 3.8.4(b) [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86]. When applicable, the Authorised Person acting as the Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio must appoint a third party to attest to the portfolio's compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement. This attestation must occur on an ongoing basis and at least annually [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e]. The requirement applies specifically to the portion of the Eligible Green Portfolio Assets invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy according to Rule 3.8.4(a) [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e].
rag_answer: The Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement is not applicable to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that are not invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy under Rule 3.8.4(a) [#P:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e]. When the requirement is applicable, the Authorised Person, acting as the Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio, must appoint a third party to attest to the portfolio's compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually [#P:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e]. The attestation must be addressed to and relied upon by the Authorised Person, confirming that during the reviewed period, the investment objectives of the Model Portfolio have been adhered to and have met the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement, and that as of the attestation date, the Model Portfolio is in compliance with these requirements [#P:d4fd2a2b-ace2-4737-aa58-c101d206a016]. This attestation is only required for assets invested under Rule 3.8.4(a), even if the portfolio includes assets under Rule 3.8.4(b) [#P:91fae359-0088-464b-ac96-ae1cfaefe3f3].

question: When doesn't the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement apply, and what must the Authorised Person do when it does?
gold_answer: The Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement is not needed for Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that are part of or follow an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86]. When it is needed, the Authorised Person managing an ADGM Green Portfolio must hire a third party to confirm compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement. This check must happen regularly and at least once a year [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e]. The rule applies to assets that fit an Acceptable Green Taxonomy as per Rule 3.8.4(a) [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e].
rag_answer: The Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to portions of the Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that are not invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy according to Rule 3.8.4(a) [#P:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e]. When the requirement does apply, the Authorised Person acting as the Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually [#P:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e]. The attestation must be addressed to and may be relied upon by the Authorised Person, specifying that during the period reviewed, the investment objectives of the Model Portfolio have been adhered to and have met the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement, and as of the date of the attestation, the Model Portfolio meets the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement [#P:d4fd2a2b-ace2-4737-aa58-c101d206a016]. This ensures that the portfolio remains compliant with the specified green investment standards, providing transparency and accountability in the management of green assets.

question: How must a Recognised Investment Exchange ensure compliance with disclosure obligations when admitting Financial Instruments to trading, and what are the specific controls an MTF must implement for Securities offered by way of an Exempt Offer?
gold_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange must maintain effective arrangements to verify that Issuers of Financial Instruments comply with disclosure obligations when admitted to trading on its market [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]. Additionally, it must assist market users in accessing public information under these obligations [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]. In parallel, an MTF admitting Securities offered by way of an Exempt Offer must have systems to ensure only Securities from such offers made on its platform are admitted [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. It must also identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made and restrict trading to no more than 200 non-Professional Clients [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. Furthermore, the MTF must comply with MIR rule 3.9.1 regarding admission to trading and allow market users to obtain Inside Information, including Offer documents relevant to the Securities [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66].
rag_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange must maintain effective arrangements to ensure that Issuers of Financial Instruments admitted to trading comply with their disclosure obligations. This includes maintaining arrangements to assist market users in accessing public information under these obligations and regularly reviewing whether the Financial Instruments meet the admission requirements [#P:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]. For an MTF admitting Securities offered by way of an Exempt Offer, it must implement specific controls: (a) admit only Securities of such Exempt Offers made on its platform, (b) identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made, (c) restrict trading to no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients, (d) comply with MIR rule 3.9.1 regarding admission to trading, and (e) allow market users to obtain Inside Information, including relevant Offer documents [#P:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. These measures ensure that both Recognised Investment Exchanges and MTFs uphold transparency and regulatory compliance in their trading activities.

question: What must a Recognised Investment Exchange do to help users get information about Financial Instruments, and what controls should an MTF have for Securities from an Exempt Offer?
gold_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange needs to have arrangements to help users access public information about Financial Instruments [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]. It should also verify that Issuers meet their disclosure obligations [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]. Meanwhile, an MTF must ensure that only Securities from Exempt Offers made on its platform are admitted [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. It should identify the people who received the Exempt Offer and limit trading to 200 non-Professional Clients [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. The MTF also needs to comply with specific trading rules and provide users with Inside Information and relevant Offer documents [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66].
rag_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange must ensure that users can access relevant information about Financial Instruments to make informed judgments about their value and associated risks. This involves considering how Members and Clients can obtain information through accepted dissemination channels or other widely accessible media, assessing any restrictions on information dissemination, and ensuring that information is not kept to restricted groups in a way that encourages contravention of Market Conduct Rules [#P:0d1a9131-1946-4552-9984-72370b2df036]. For an MTF admitting Securities from an Exempt Offer, it must have systems and controls to admit only Securities from Exempt Offers made on its platform, identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made, restrict trading to no more than 200 non-Professional Clients, comply with relevant admission rules, and allow market users to obtain Inside Information, including Offer documents [#P:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. These measures ensure transparency and compliance with regulatory requirements, facilitating a fair and orderly market environment.

question: Under what conditions can an Issuer make an Exempt Offer to 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients when seeking admission of its Securities to a Multilateral Trading Facility, and how does this relate to the FSMR's prescribed circumstances for Exempt Offers?
gold_answer: An Issuer may make an Exempt Offer to no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients when seeking admission of its Securities to a Multilateral Trading Facility (MTF) under MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]. This is aligned with the FSMR's prescribed circumstances for Exempt Offers, specifically under section 61(3)(a), which allows for an Offer directed at no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties, provided the Securities are offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc].
rag_answer: An Issuer can make an Exempt Offer to 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients when seeking admission of its Securities to a Multilateral Trading Facility (MTF) under specific conditions prescribed by the FSRA. This is allowed under MKT Rule 4.3.1(13), which permits such an offer provided the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via an MTF [#P:20fb6d34-d5a9-4518-a07a-8b2b46202fa8]. The offer must not be aggregated with the limit of 50 Persons under MKT Rule 4.3.1(2) [#P:20fb6d34-d5a9-4518-a07a-8b2b46202fa8]. Additionally, the Issuer may simultaneously make an Exempt Offer to an unlimited number of Professional Clients under MKT Rule 4.3.1(1) [#P:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]. The Issuer must ensure that a Product Summary Note is provided to investors, highlighting key information and not containing any false or misleading statements [#P:20fb6d34-d5a9-4518-a07a-8b2b46202fa8]. The Issuer must also notify the Regulator of its intention to provide a Product Summary Note at least ten Business Days prior to the Exempt Offer [#P:20fb6d34-d5a9-4518-a07a-8b2b46202fa8]. This framework ensures that the offer is conducted transparently and in compliance with regulatory requirements.

question: When can an Issuer offer Securities to 200 people who aren't Professional Clients on a Multilateral Trading Facility, and how does this fit with the FSMR's rules?
gold_answer: An Issuer can offer Securities to up to 200 people who aren't Professional Clients on a Multilateral Trading Facility (MTF) under MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]. This fits with the FSMR's rules, which allow such an Offer if it's directed at no more than 200 non-Professional Clients or Market Counterparties, and the Securities are offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc].
rag_answer: An Issuer can offer Securities to up to 200 individuals who are not Professional Clients on a Multilateral Trading Facility (MTF) under specific conditions outlined in the ADGM/FSRA regulations. This is permissible when the Securities are to be admitted to trading on an MTF, as per MKT Rule 4.3.1(13). The Issuer may also utilize an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more circumstances within MKT Rule 4.3.1, except for MKT Rule 4.3.1(2) [#P:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]. Additionally, the obligation to issue a Prospectus under Section 61(3) of FSMR does not apply to an Exempt Offer, which includes offers directed at Professional Clients other than natural persons, offers directed at fewer than 50 persons in any 12-month period excluding Professional Clients who are not natural persons, or where the total consideration to acquire Securities is at least USD 100,000 [#P:e0ab4647-3da5-4379-897b-c392a59b8ed5]. Therefore, an Issuer can make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to 200 non-Professional Clients and an unlimited number of Professional Clients, provided these conditions are met.

question: When a Recognised Body operates a Recognised Investment Exchange or an Authorised Person operates a Multilateral Trading Facility or an Organised Trading Facility in relation to Accepted Spot Commodities, how must the Regulator assess the application for a Financial Services Permission?
